thread.title: FDA Adds Thousands of Medical Device Records to Public Website
thread.title_full: FDA Adds Thousands of Medical Device Records to Public Website

author: AAMI
title: FDA Adds Thousands of Medical Device Records to Public Website
text:
The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has added a trove of data—including information on clearances, adverse events, and recalls—on thousands of medical devices to a publicly accessible website, a move that the agency describes as supporting innovation and research.
Specifically, the information added to OpenFDA includes data on 6,000 device classification records, 24,000 registrations of device companies and establishments, company listings of more than 100,000 devices, 30,000 device premarket approvals, 141,000 clearances through the 510(k) program, 9,500 records on device recalls, and 4.2 million records on adverse events.
In a blog post on FDAVoice , the agency says that the interface on the platform is easy to use and supports the creation of devices that would benefit the public.
“For example, developers could develop a smartphone app to search all the recalls associated with a particularly type of device or find all companies that manufacture certain types of devices,” reads the blog post written by Taha Kass-Hout, Roselie A. Bright, and Ann Ferriter, all with the FDA.
The agency says that proprietary information is not included. “The information doesn’t contain anything that potentially could be used to identify individuals or reveal confidential commercial information,” according to the post.
The agency concedes that there are limits to the data, noting that some query results may be incomplete and that if a manufacturer’s name is listed with different spellings, search results could be fragmented.
“Moreover, the types of information that FDA has collected has changed over the years, which can make it difficult to look at data over time,” reads the post. “Also, the data may not have enough information to establish cause and effect, incidence, or prevalence.”
